&bibliography; random-networks-configuration Random graphs with general degree distributions: The configuration model
Constructing graphs with a given degree distribution
Configuration model: - choose a degree sequence N(k) = N P(k) - give the nodes k stubs according to N(k) - connect stubs randomly
[M. E. J. Newman, S. H. Strogatz, and D. J. Watts, Phys. Rev. E 64, 026118 (2001)]
Necessary condition for the graph construction?
Theory of general random graphs: Looks at a characteristic member of the ensemble of graphs with given degree distribution The theoretical concept needed for the analysis is the generating function [H. Wilf, Generatingfunctionology (1994)]
configuration-generating-functions Generating functions
Node degree generating function
G_0 (x) = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} p(k) x^k
Finding p(k) and degree moments from the generating function:
p(k) = \frac{1}{k!} \frac{d^k G_0}{dx^k} \bigg|_{x=0}
\langle k_n \rangle = \sum_{k} k^n p(k) = \left[ \left( x \frac{d}{dx} \right)^n G_0(x) \right] \bigg|_{x=1}
If a certain property is described by a gen. function, then its sum over m independent realizations is generated by the mth power of the gen. function.
e.g. The generating function for the sum of the degrees of two nodes is [G_0(x)]^2
Generating function for the degree of nodes at the end of a random edge
G_1 (x) = \frac { \sum_{k} k p(k) x^{k-1} } { \sum_{k} k p(k) } = \frac { G_0'(x) }{ G_0'(1) }
[M. E. J. Newman, S. H. Strogatz, D. J. Watts, Phys. Rev. E 64, 026118 (2001)]
Generating functions for connected components
P_s: distribution of component sizes
H_0 (x) = \sum_{s=0}^{\infty} p_s(k) x^s
H_1 (x) = \frac { \sum_{k} k [H_1(x)]^{k-1} } { \sum_{k} k p(k) } = x G_1 ( H_1(x))
H_0 (x) = x G_0 ( H_1(x))
Existence of a giant connected cluster
Average size of marked clusters
\langle s \rangle = H_0'(1) = 1 + \frac{ G_0'(1) } { 1 - G_1'(1) }
diverges when
G_1'(1) = \frac { \sum_{k} k p(k) } { \sum_{k} k (k-1) p(k) } = x G_1 ( H_1(x)) = 1
Equivalent to:
\frac{ \langle k^2 \rangle } { \langle k \rangle } = 2
A giant connected component exists if the graph is sufficiently heterogeneous.
